articles.headline: U.S. Fines Automakers Hyundai and Kia for Misstating Mileage
articles.snippet: Hyundai and Kia, owned by the Hyundai Motor Group, will pay a combined $300 million for overstating their fuel-economy standards.
articles.abstract: Hyundai and Kia, owned by the Hyundai Motor Group, will pay a combined $300 million for overstating their fuel-economy standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the largest-ever penalty for a violation of the Clean Air Act, the Korean automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors will pay the federal government a combined $300 million as part of a settlement for overstating vehicle fuel-economy standards on 1.2 million cars, Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency officials said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: On Election’s Eve, G.O.P. Is Confident, but Voters Are Sour
articles.snippet: Republicans entered the end of the most expensive midterm campaign in American history confident they will take control of the Senate, but voter interest is low.
articles.abstract: Republicans entered the end of the most expensive midterm campaign in American history confident they will take control of the Senate, but voter interest is low.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most expensive midterm campaign in American history stumbled into Election Day on Tuesday with voters’ interest at record lows and their divisions deep over what they want their government to do in President Obama’s final two years.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Recalled G.M. Cars Remain Unrepaired
articles.snippet: Owners of vehicles recalled over a faulty, and deadly, ignition switch problem say they are still waiting for repairs and sometimes get the runaround at dealerships.
articles.abstract: Owners of vehicles recalled over a faulty, and deadly, ignition switch problem say they are still waiting for repairs and sometimes get the runaround at dealerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: YONKERS — Nearly nine months after General Motors began recalling millions of its cars for a dangerously defective ignition switch, almost half of the vehicles still have not been fixed.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Ideas to Improve Financial Lives, From the Treasurer’s Office
articles.snippet: State and local treasurers have introduced innovative programs and policies aimed at lifting the fortunes of low- and moderate-income people.
articles.abstract: State and local treasurers have introduced innovative programs and policies aimed at lifting the fortunes of low- and moderate-income people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Known primarily as number crunchers and tax collectors, treasurers for state and local governments traditionally were limited to activities like processing payrolls, managing budgets, safeguarding pensions and being the target of accountant jokes.

articles.headline: In Traveling to the Stars, Risk and Cost
articles.snippet: Two recent accidents, one of them fatal, involving commercial rockets have underscored the high risks and soaring costs involved in any spaceflight.
articles.abstract: Two recent accidents, one of them fatal, involving commercial rockets have underscored the high risks and soaring costs involved in any spaceflight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Space travel has long been the preserve of governments and sci-fi fans, but in recent years a crop of new commercial ventures, often backed by billionaire entrepreneurs, has sought to get into the race.

articles.headline: Hollywood Works to Maintain Its World Dominance
articles.snippet: At the American Film Market, some in the business will be worrying about the subtle shifts away from their products in other countries.
articles.abstract: At the American Film Market, some in the business will be worrying about the subtle shifts away from their products in other countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Twice in the last few months, there was a faint knock on the door of American supremacy in the global film market.

articles.headline: Sex and Drug Claims at Investment Bank Jefferies Draw Risky Retort
articles.snippet: Scandalous accusations made against a managing director at the investment bank Jefferies as part of a divorce and custody filing have become the talk of Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Scandalous accusations made against a managing director at the investment bank Jefferies as part of a divorce and custody filing have become the talk of Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We went to our partners in health care investment banking yesterday afternoon and said, ‘The two of us are going to go take a drug test, and do you want to join us?’ ”

articles.headline: Role for Russia Gives Iran Talks a Possible Boost
articles.snippet: Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West.
articles.abstract: Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West, according to officials and diplomats involved in the negotiations, potentially a major breakthrough in talks that have until now been deadlocked.

articles.headline: Riding Wave of Discontent, G.O.P. Takes Senate
articles.snippet: Republicans picked up seats in Arkansas, West Virginia, Montana, South Dakota, Colorado, North Carolina and Iowa, consolidating their power on Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: Republicans picked up seats in Arkansas, West Virginia, Montana, South Dakota, Colorado, North Carolina and Iowa, consolidating their power on Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Resurgent Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday night, expanded their hold on the House, and defended some of the most closely contested governors’ races, in a repudiation of President Obama that will reorder the political map in his final years in office.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker
